Inference: High water usage during weather-based irrigation increases and high temperatures indicates irrigation responding to heat-driven moisture loss
Description: The system delivers more water when weather logic and temperature jointly signal drying conditions.
short rationale: Heat-driven demand response; low privacy risk.

Inference: High water usage during weather-based irrigation reductions and high humidity indicates irrigation is not adapting correctly to moisture-rich air
Description: Watering remains high despite conditions that normally reduce irrigation demand.

Inference: Low water usage during weather-based reductions and low temperatures reflects natural cooling-driven irrigation suppression
Description: Cool weather decreases evaporative demand, allowing irrigation cycles to shrink.
short rationale: Appropriate reduction from cool temps; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage rising during weather-based increases and low humidity indicates strong atmospheric drying requiring compensation
Description: Dry air and system adjustments work together to counter evaporation.

Inference: Water usage falling during weather-based reductions and high humidity suggests natural environmental moisture supporting reduced irrigation needs
Description: Humid air slows evaporation, allowing for water-saving behavior.

Inference: Water usage rising despite weather-based reductions during high temperatures indicates irrigation override due to excessive heat
Description: Temperature conditions push irrigation upward even though the weather system signals reductions.
short rationale: Heat overrides reduction logic; moderate concern.

Inference: Weather-based increases paired with rising water usage during temperature spikes indicate heat-driven irrigation scaling
Description: The system increases irrigation when temperatures rise and dryness intensifies.

Inference: Weather-based increases paired with stable water usage during high temperatures indicate a possible irrigation capacity limit
Description: The system wants to irrigate more but may be restricted by system output constraints.

Inference: Weather-based reductions with rising water usage during cooling periods indicate non-weather irrigation triggers
Description: Water usage rises due to schedules or programming rather than environmental need.

Inference: Water usage rising during stable temperatures and stable humidity suggests irrigation decisions are schedule-driven
Description: Environmental factors remain unchanged, so irrigation increases must derive from internal schedules.

Inference: Water usage falling during rising temperatures and falling humidity suggests irrigation misalignment with environmental stress
Description: Environmental drying increases, but irrigation fails to respond.

Inference: Simultaneous spikes in temperature, weather-based increases, and water usage indicate strong alignment with climatic stress patterns
Description: The system reacts accurately when heat increases water-loss rates.
short rationale: Aligned response to heat; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Humidity spikes causing weather-based reductions combined with stable water usage suggest irrigation output is unresponsive to moisture-rich conditions
Description: Humidity reduction logic is not influencing actual irrigation volume.
short rationale: Reduction commands not reflected in output.

Inference: Humidity drops causing weather-based increases paired with rising water usage indicate atmospheric drying is correctly detected
Description: The system increases irrigation as moisture in the air decreases.
short rationale: Correct response to drying air; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage rising dramatically during low humidity and low temperature suggests deep soil dryness rather than atmospheric-driven need
Description: Cool air reduces evaporation, so high usage likely compensates for soil conditions.
short rationale: Deep dryness despite favorable air; moderate concern.

Inference: Water usage falling during high temperature and high humidity suggests rainfall or dew not directly detected in weather logs
Description: Moisture-rich conditions allow irrigation cycles to shrink even when temperatures rise.
short rationale: Unlogged moisture reducing use; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage falling rapidly after humidity spikes and weather-based reductions indicates natural hydration effects
Description: Moisture-rich air or rainfall reduces the need for irrigation.
short rationale: Natural hydration lowering use; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage rising despite humidity spikes and weather-based reductions indicates misconfiguration or persistent soil dryness
Description: The system reduces watering based on humidity, but dryness still requires high irrigation.

Inference: Weather-based increases during falling humidity and stable temperatures with rising water usage suggest humidity-centric irrigation control
Description: Dry air influences irrigation decisions more than temperature signals.

Inference: Weather-based reductions during rising humidity and stable temperature with falling water usage indicate efficient irrigation conservation
Description: The system responds correctly to atmospheric moisture, reducing output.
short rationale: Efficient conservation with humidity; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage remaining high during weather-based reductions and low temperatures indicates schedule rigidity
Description: Irrigation timing is fixed regardless of environmental factors.

Inference: Water usage remaining low during weather-based increases and high temperatures indicates under-watering risk
Description: The system identifies drying conditions but water output does not increase accordingly.

Inference: Water usage rising at night during low temperatures despite weather-based reductions suggests misaligned watering schedules
Description: Nighttime cooling normally reduces irrigation need, but system configuration overrides environmental logic.
short rationale: Misaligned night watering; moderate operational concern.

Inference: Water usage dropping at night during high humidity and weather-based reductions reflects optimal conservation behavior
Description: Environmental moisture and system logic reduce water output effectively.
short rationale: Optimal night conservation; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage rising sharply during midday temperature peaks while weather logs show irrigation increases indicates diurnal demand matching
Description: Irrigation scales correctly with peak daytime dryness.
short rationale: Daytime dryness response; low privacy risk.

Inference: Water usage falling sharply during morning humidity peaks despite weather increases suggests condensation or dew providing moisture
Description: Environmental moisture inputs reduce irrigation demand unexpectedly.

Inference: Stable water usage during volatile temperature and humidity conditions indicates irrigation insensitivity to environmental fluctuations
Description: The system may be configured with fixed watering amounts or durations.

Inference: Large water usage variability during stable temperature and humidity suggests irrigation driven by weather forecast data rather than current conditions
Description: System behavior depends on predicted conditions instead of real-time environmental data.

Inference: Weather-based increases with minimal water usage rise during humidity drops indicate irrigation throttling or low-capacity mode
Description: The system wants to irrigate more but physical delivery does not scale accordingly.

Inference: Weather-based reductions with water usage rising during humidity increases indicate competing control systems
Description: One system reduces irrigation due to humidity while another increases it due to soil or schedule triggers.
